content.description: Easily identifiable by the unique white panel that sits atop of it.  Another rowdy mini-route up the right-hand splitter, which is just a fake-news crack--mostly just a seam with pods and boxes thrown in to permit more rad trad face climbing. The pro is fiddly, but better than its neighbor to the left, and the climbing is engaging until the anchor is clipped.

climbs.name: Rockin' Sloppy Moccs with Socks On

content.description:
The crag warm-up, and a good one at that, with a real mixed bag of crack sizes and situations on mostly very good Schnebly. 

 Start up the left side of the lower pillar, on a very bizarre stair-stepped crimp ladder with a micro-crack in the corner to the pillar top. Fingers quickly open to fat-fingers and tight-hands to the obvious bombay. Pull into and out of the steep bombay (body-English crux) via a tight-hand crack, and finish on awkward steep hands to a shelf.

A short, full-value Schnebly outing which is a trad climb, and has cracks (sometimes 2, sometimes 3), but is very much a sequential face climb with rad movement and just-adequate pro. Unique pod-jams, laybacks, crimps, and medley features. This is a good one, worth working out, which is easy to do if you set up a TR with a swing over on lower from Rockin'.
A sunny, small, secluded mini-crag of high-quality Schnebly with maximum sun exposure (after late morning) for those cold winter days.
